definitions: A disorder caused by excessive growth hormone secretion in adults leading to tissue and bone enlargement.
Pathologic overproduction of growth hormone after epiphyseal closure, producing enlargement of extremities and soft tissues.
A condition typically driven by a pituitary tumor that elevates GH (and often IGF-1) in adulthood.
Excess adult GH resulting in progressive enlargement of hands, feet, jaw, and other tissues.
A chronic endocrine disorder where growth hormone is high in adults, causing abnormal growth of bones and organs.
Adult-onset GH excess that enlarges connective tissue and bones rather than increasing height.
A hormonal disorder characterized by adult GH hypersecretion with systemic effects (metabolic, cardiovascular, structural).
The clinical syndrome of adult growth hormone excess, commonly associated with pituitary adenoma and elevated IGF-1.
Synthetic derivatives of testosterone that promote muscle growth and strength but carry major health risks.
Testosterone-like compounds designed to increase anabolic (tissue-building) effects and androgenic effects.
Performance-enhancing drugs that can increase muscle mass via androgen receptor–mediated effects on protein synthesis.
Exogenous steroid hormones used illicitly to enhance hypertrophy, strength, and recovery.
Synthetic androgens that may boost lean mass while increasing risk of cardiovascular, hepatic, and endocrine complications.
Hormone-like drugs that mimic testosterone and can alter physiology and behavior when abused.
Compounds that enhance muscle-building processes but may suppress endogenous hormone production.
A class of banned substances used to increase performance through anabolic signaling and accelerated recovery.
Drugs that stimulate beta-adrenergic receptors; some are abused to increase lean mass and reduce fat mass.
Agents that activate β-receptors, producing effects such as bronchodilation and altered metabolism.
Substances that mimic sympathetic stimulation at beta receptors, sometimes used illicitly for body composition changes.
Pharmacologic compounds that bind beta-adrenergic receptors and can influence muscle and fat tissue.
Drugs that stimulate the sympathetic system via β-receptors and may have performance-related effects in some contexts.
Receptor agonists that can increase metabolic rate and, in some cases, promote anabolic-like changes.
Medications (often for asthma) that may be banned or restricted in sport depending on type/dose/route.
Beta-receptor stimulants whose misuse can carry cardiovascular risk and violate anti-doping rules.
Essential amino acids leucine, isoleucine, and valine involved in muscle metabolism.
Three essential amino acids with branched side chains that can be oxidized in skeletal muscle.
Amino acids commonly associated with stimulation of muscle protein synthesis, especially via leucine signaling.
Leucine, isoleucine, and valine—essential amino acids important for recovery and training adaptation.
A subset of EAAs often supplemented for perceived recovery benefits and reduced muscle breakdown.
Essential amino acids that may serve as fuel during exercise and support post-exercise repair.
Amino acids with branched structures that are metabolized largely in muscle rather than liver.
The trio of essential amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, valine) central to muscle protein turnover.
A product taken orally to supplement the diet with nutrients or other substances.
An ingested product intended to add to dietary intake (e.g., vitamins, minerals, herbs, amino acids).
Oral products marketed to support health or performance beyond normal food intake.
A non-food product consumed to increase nutrient intake or deliver bioactive compounds.
Products such as powders, pills, capsules, or liquids used to augment the diet.
A category including nutrients and performance products with variable evidence and quality control.
Oral compounds used to fill nutritional gaps or attempt to enhance performance or recovery.
In sport context, a product intended to support nutrition/performance but requiring risk screening for contamination.
Any substance, device, or practice that enhances energy production, use, or recovery to improve performance.
An intervention designed to improve physical performance capacity or output.
A method or agent that improves performance by increasing work capacity or reducing fatigue.
Any performance-enhancing strategy (nutritional, mechanical, psychological, pharmacological, or training-based).
A tool or substance used to boost performance, endurance, strength, or recovery.
A performance aid that improves efficiency, power output, or readiness for competition.
Anything that increases performance by improving physiological, biomechanical, or psychological factors.
A broad category of performance enhancers, ranging from legal nutrition strategies to banned drugs.
A substance or factor that reduces athletic performance.
Any intervention or condition that impairs performance output or capacity.
An agent that decreases power, endurance, or recovery and worsens performance.
A performance-degrading factor, opposite of an ergogenic aid.
A substance or behavior that reduces work capacity or increases fatigue.
Anything that diminishes performance efficiency or physical output.
A factor that negatively affects performance via physiological, psychological, or biomechanical mechanisms.
A performance inhibitor that interferes with energy production, neuromuscular function, or recovery.
A hormone that stimulates red blood cell production in the bone marrow.
A renal-derived hormone that increases erythropoiesis, raising oxygen-carrying capacity.
A hormone used clinically for anemia but abused in sport to enhance endurance via increased RBC mass.
A blood-forming hormone that can improve oxygen delivery when RBC count rises.
A physiological signal (mainly from kidneys) that responds to low oxygen by increasing red blood cell production.
A hormone that increases hematocrit/hemoglobin when elevated, affecting aerobic performance potential.
A banned/regulated performance-enhancing drug when used illicitly to increase oxygen transport.
A hormone that boosts RBC synthesis but whose misuse increases blood viscosity and cardiovascular risk.
Amino acids the body cannot synthesize and must obtain from the diet.
Diet-required amino acids necessary for protein synthesis and normal function.
Indispensable amino acids that must be consumed because endogenous production is insufficient.
The amino acids that must come from food to support growth, repair, and muscle protein synthesis.
Amino acids that are required in the diet to prevent deficiency and maintain protein balance.
Dietary amino acids that the body cannot make in adequate amounts for metabolic needs.
Amino acids that must be ingested to fully support tissue repair and adaptation.
The subset of amino acids that are nutritionally required because humans cannot synthesize them.
A hormone that stimulates growth, cell reproduction, and regeneration; misuse can cause serious health problems.
A pituitary hormone that promotes growth and influences metabolism directly and via IGF-1.
Somatotropin—an endocrine hormone that affects tissue growth, nutrient partitioning, and recovery processes.
A hormone sometimes abused for performance or physique goals despite limited benefits and significant risks.
A pituitary-derived hormone that increases IGF-1 signaling and influences protein and fat metabolism.
A growth-regulating hormone whose excess in adults can contribute to acromegaly-like effects.
A hormone that supports growth and repair but is banned/misused in sport with potential adverse outcomes.
An anabolic-associated hormone that affects metabolism and growth pathways, with misuse linked to edema, insulin resistance, and tissue overgrowth.
The breakdown of triglycerides into free fatty acids and glycerol for energy use.
Hydrolysis of stored fat into fatty acids that can be oxidized and glycerol that can enter metabolism.
A metabolic process that mobilizes fat stores by splitting triglycerides.
Fat breakdown that increases circulating free fatty acids for use as fuel.
The catabolic pathway that releases fatty acids from adipose tissue triglycerides.
The process of mobilizing stored fat for energy, especially during fasting or endurance exercise.
Triglyceride breakdown into components used for oxidation or gluconeogenesis (via glycerol).
A fuel-mobilization process where stored fat is converted into usable substrates for metabolism.
The ability of muscle to resist changes in pH during high-intensity exercise by buffering hydrogen ions.
A muscle’s capacity to neutralize or tolerate acid-base disturbances during intense glycolytic work.
Physiological ability to limit intramuscular pH drop when H+ accumulates during hard efforts.
The capability of muscle to maintain pH stability during fatiguing, high-intensity exercise.
A performance-related trait affecting tolerance to metabolic acidosis during repeated sprints or intervals.
The muscle-level defense against excessive acidity, helping sustain force and power output.
Capacity to buffer H+ produced during ATP hydrolysis and intense glycolysis, delaying fatigue.
A factor contributing to high-intensity performance by resisting pH decline in working muscle.
A psychological disorder characterized by obsessive belief that one’s muscles are insufficiently developed.
A body image disturbance where a person perceives themselves as not muscular enough despite adequate size.
A condition involving compulsive concerns about muscularity leading to distress and impaired functioning.
An obsessive focus on being leaner/more muscular that can drive harmful training or dietary behaviors.
A subtype of body dysmorphic disorder centered on perceived lack of muscularity.
A body image disorder associated with excessive exercise, rigid diet rules, and sometimes substance misuse.
Persistent preoccupation with muscular inadequacy that affects behavior and self-esteem.
A psychological pattern where perceived “smallness” persists regardless of actual muscular development.
Unannounced testing procedures used to detect banned performance-enhancing substances.
Drug tests conducted without prior notice to reduce evasion and deter doping.
No-advance-warning anti-doping tests intended to identify prohibited substances or methods.
Testing scheduled unpredictably to improve detection probability of banned agents.
A deterrence strategy where athletes can be tested at any time without warning.
Anti-doping tests performed on a random/unannounced basis to increase compliance.
A monitoring system using surprise tests to reduce timing strategies for drug use.
Unpredictable substance testing designed to detect prohibited performance-enhancing drug use.
The practice of using multiple performance-enhancing substances simultaneously to amplify effects.
Combining several drugs or supplements at the same time in an attempt to increase performance outcomes.
Using multiple agents concurrently to target different mechanisms or increase total dosing impact.
A doping strategy involving more than one substance to enhance anabolic or recovery effects.
Simultaneous use of multiple performance-enhancing compounds to attempt synergistic results.
Combining different substances (often anabolic agents) to maximize perceived gains.
The concurrent administration of multiple ergogenic drugs, increasing complexity and risk.
A high-risk practice of mixing multiple performance-enhancing substances to intensify effects.
A primary male sex hormone that plays a key role in muscle growth, strength, and recovery.
An androgen hormone involved in development of male characteristics and regulation of protein metabolism.
A steroid hormone that binds androgen receptors influencing muscle protein synthesis and neuromuscular function.
A hormone important for libido, red blood cell production, and muscle and bone maintenance.
The primary androgen that supports anabolic processes and recovery when within healthy physiological ranges.
A sex hormone that affects body composition, strength potential, and training adaptation.
A steroid hormone that can be administered exogenously as an anabolic-androgenic drug (banned in sport).
An androgen influencing muscle mass and performance potential, with deficiency or excess impacting health.
The production of heat through metabolic processes.
Heat generation resulting from energy expenditure in the body.
Metabolic heat production that contributes to total energy expenditure.
The physiological process of producing heat, often increased by activity, diet, or stimulants.
Heat generation via metabolism, including basal metabolism and diet-induced thermogenesis.
The conversion of chemical energy into heat during metabolic reactions.
A component of energy balance describing heat output from metabolism and activity.
Body heat production that can rise with sympathetic stimulation, feeding, or environmental demands.
The widening of blood vessels, increasing blood flow to tissues.
An increase in vessel diameter due to relaxation of smooth muscle in the vessel wall.
A cardiovascular response that decreases vascular resistance and enhances tissue perfusion.
Expansion of arterioles/arteries that increases blood delivery and can lower blood pressure.
A process that improves blood flow by reducing constriction in the vasculature.
Relaxation-driven enlargement of blood vessels that raises local or systemic blood flow.
A mechanism that increases perfusion to working muscle during exercise.
Widening of vessels that reduces resistance and increases blood flow, often mediated by nitric oxide and local metabolites.
